captions.text:
Good Morning Hank. It's Wednesday, January
30th and today's video comes to you in one
part. Part one: I am not a Pornographer.

Hank, you may remember that almost three years
ago my first novel, Looking for Alaska, was

published. I just found out that Looking for
Alaska is about to be taught to 11th grade

english students at Depew High school, outside
of Buffalo, New York. Alaska is taught in

a lot of English classes around the country,
but it's still pretty awesome to hear that

someone is gonna like, teach your book in
a regular english class, and people are gonna
read it closely and think hard about it.

So here's what happened. Because there are
a few scenes in Looking for Alaska that some

people find controversial, the Depew High
School administrators and English teachers

got together, and they wrote a letter saying,
'We're gonna teach this book. We think it's

pretty good. If you're okay with your kid
being taught this book, please sign this permission

slip, otherwise the kid will read some other
book.' So parents who are cool with their

kids reading Looking for Alaska get to have
their kids read Looking for Alaska, and parents

who aren't cool with it get to have their
kids read some other book.

But there were a few people who weren't happy
with this solution. These people didn't actually

have kids who are in the 11th grade... but
no matter. They think my book is pornographic

and that it will cause immoral thoughts and
actions in children. These people believe

that no one should be allowed to read the
book, even those people whose parents signed
the permission slip.
*Grumbles*

Now Hank, it's no secret that I like for things
to be about me, but this really isn't. Still

I have to tell you that when you're told that
the novel that you wrote for teenagers is

pornography, you start to feel a little bit,
mmm... mad. I don't know exactly what it is

that bothers me about that characterization.
I mean, it's not the -ography. I wouldn't

be mad if someone was like, 'We must get this
book out of our classrooms; it's full of geography!'

Or, 'No teenager should ever have to read
this disgusting work of lexicography.'

No Hank, it's not the -graphy that bothers
me. It's the porn. Pornography is designed

to titillate. Hank, I don't think there's
a single halfway-normal person in the world

who would find a single thing in my book in
anyway arousing. There is one very frank sex

scene. It is awkward, un-fun, disastrous,
and wholly unerotic. Hank the whole reason

that scene in question exists in Looking for
Alaska is because I wanted to draw contrast

between that scene, when there is a lot of
physical intimacy but it's ultimately very

emotionally empty, and the scene that immediately
follows it, when there is not a serious physical

interaction, but there's this intense emotional
connection.

The argument here is that physical intimacy
can never stand in for emotional closeness.

And that when teenagers attempt to conflate
these ideas, it inevitably fails. Hank, it

doesn't take a deeply critical understanding
of literature to realise that Looking for

Alaska is arguing against vapid physical interactions,
not for them.

Now Hank, some people are gonna say that kids
don't have the critical sophistication when

they're reading to understand that. And I
have a message for those people. Shut up and

stop condescending to teenagers. Do you seriously
think that teenagers aren't able to read critically?

When they read George Orwell's Animal Farm
do they head out to the pig farms to kill

all the pigs because they're about to become
communist autocrats? When they read Huck Finn

do they think that Huck should turn Jim in
because the demented conscience of the community

says so? When they read Waiting for Godot
do they think that it's cool to just sit around

and do nothing? Well, probably they do actually,
that one doesn't really work toward my point.

Now obviously Hank, I don't think that a few
parents should get to decide what the kids

of other parents read in school. Those parents
are qualified to sign or not sign that permission

slip as they see fit. And to speak frankly
Hank, it also pisses me off when small groups

of well-organized would-be book banners try
to take over America's public school systems.

Now fortunately in Depew, there are a lot
of teachers and school administrators and

school board members who are standing up for
my book and for the right of teachers to teach

it, and for the right of parents to choose
to have it taught to their kids.

But Hank, sometimes these people who make
stands for intellectual freedom can feel like

they're going it alone. Which is why I'd like
to ask from the bottom of my heart that any

nerdfighters that live in or around Depew
go to the school board meeting on February

5th. (Info in the sidebar.) Also, I've written
a letter in defense of the teachers who would

like to teach my book. If you'd like to write
a letter, send it to sparksflyup at gmail

dot com and I'll be sure to forward it on.
Hank, thanks to you and all the nerdfighters
in advance for your emails.

comments.author: Hirobian

comments.text:
I've recently been watching old vlogbrothers videos and came across this 
one that caught my attention. 

It's back from 2008 and John is talking about his book, Looking for Alaska. 
As I was listening to what he was saying about parents at a school not 
wanting their children or others to read the book, I realized if you took 
out the book and substituted other issues from our society in, it speaks 
volumes.

Just because you don't approve of something doesn't mean we must take it 
away from all. You should have the right to choose, no matter.﻿
comments.author: Autumn Mikita

comments.text:
My public high school 11th grade American History class read Snow Falling 
on Cedars ... which definitely had a mix of sexual situations that were 
awkward and some others (or one other) that were pretty easily seen as 
erotic. Sexual subtext was significant and a serious social aspect to some 
of the points in the book (on top of culture, society, civilization, 
prejudice, love, hate, and human nature as a whole). Seemed perfectly 
fitting for the class and did require a permission slip, but I don't think 
anyone ended up passing on it. In hindsight the only thing I regret a bit 
is donating my copy to the class ... but I'm sure they've gotten good use 
out of it since.﻿

comments.author: Eduardo Olvera

comments.text:
Parents trying to "protect" teenagers from controversial books like Alaska 
(which, btw, is very mild in nature compared to books like Animal Farm and 
Heart of Darkness) is one of the main reasons why we teens sometimes 
despise adults with a passion. You treat us like mindless toddlers, yet 
expect us to be "prim and proper" like adults. That's ridiculous, unfair, 
and immature at best.﻿
comments.author: Nicole Chung

comments.text:
I completely agree with you. I read Trainspotting when I was around 15-16 
and I didn't become a Scottish Junkie who has a battle with kicking the 
habit, suppositories, over dosing, and/or stealing a lot of money from some 
incredibly shifty friends you managed to pick up since you were fairly 
young. Except for one, but who could steal from Spud, the poor soul... 
I also believe that it's safe to say that I will never partake in a wide 
amount of drugs or the previously stated experiences, because despite now 
knowing how to "cook up", I also know how incredibly horrifying a serious 
drug addiction is. Not only on your health, not only on your relationships, 
but also on your mind. I still cannot unsee that dead baby with the 
spinning head on the ceiling from the movie... I think that baby alone is 
reason enough for me to be pretty damn near straight edge. I am also 
Canadian, and born in Canada, so there is some debate about whether I could 
ever be Scottish. 

All of that being said, I would let our sons read your books at possibly 
any age (after I read them myself because I would currently be reading them 
if I wasn't struggling with Life of Pi and trying to figure out how a rat's 
anus is a vital piece of imagery that Yann Martel decided any and all 
readers required. If I wasn't able to put a meaning behind that scene with 
the rat, the detail of that rat's anus would probably be the only thing I 
take from that book. That, and my argument against his Agnostic statements. 
I'm only half way, though, so we'll see how this goes. Read Fight Club in 
three days. It's been... Weeks with this book. I'm looking SO incredibly 
forward to reading all of your novels, you have no idea.﻿

I never knew you were this cool. I read about this issue in AP Language. I 
also read the letter you wrote about this, and I always thought you were 
one of those popular writers,who are very detached from their fan base. 
That is, until I started watching these videos. I think it's amazing how 
you geek out about stuff just as much as I do, and I'm very happy that 
people like you make such a strong impression on my generation. Also, I 
have watched so many of Hank's videos because of AP Bio, and that's how I 
actually started watching these videos. So I'm very grateful to him as 
well. You two are fine examples for all of nerdkind.﻿

comments.text:
I believe that's because the videos on this channel were originally started 
as a means of allowing the two brothers (John and Hank) to reconnect with 
one another. They forbade themselves from communicating through any method 
aside from vlogs, and uploaded videos every day. People liked it, and I 
believe that the two of them continue addressing the videos to one another 
like that as a means of preserving, to some extent, the original spirit of 
those early videos.

+Scheurthiaume I read that part about 5 times trying to understand it, and 
NO they didnt do it, they just came close. Very heavy make out session. And 
then they were like ok we are going to leave in a few days and go somewhere 
else away from these people who hold us to our sin but until then we'll be 
free and happy and have more kids but until then we will just meet secretly 
and make out. and then Dimesdale (preacher dude) is like oh right my 
daughter is right over there and I've never actually met her umm can I meet 
her and then Pearl is like I wont come across the creek without mom wearing 
her A and then Hester is like fine I'll put it back on for a few days, and 
then when we leave I'll never put it on again. But of course they dont 
leave when planned because he dies right after telling everyone, but 
eventually Hester does leave with Pearl and they go back to England where 
Hester was actually royalty and so Pearl gets to be royalty and she has 
money from Chillingsworth because when he died he left everything to her, 
and so she lives happily ever after in England and Hester eventually comes 
back to America, basically to die, and she dies and is burried next to 
Dimesdale except not exactly right next to him because they wernt married 
and they have a shared tombstone with an A on it. The end. 
Most of this I didnt get from reading the book, but from talking to an 
English/History teacher who is a family friend and she explained everything 
to me. So... ya, thats what happened to the best of my understanding.

comments.text:
When you condescend towards the future of your country, how does that 
benefit anyone in any way? I am not a "dumb teen" I am a human, mature and 
old enough to make conscious decisions about how I think, act and 
comprehend the world around me, especially when it comes to sex. I want to 
be informed about intimacy. it's human nature to need intimacy, so why is 
it so dang taboo? Teenagers in the eleventh grade who aren't allowed to 
view something even slightly sexual aren't going to do well when it comes 
time to actually do those things, being well informed about the natural 
occurrence that is sex isn't going to damage anyone, it will infact better 
prepare them. Don't think I don't have a voice, because my voice and my 
peers voices will be the most prominent sooner than later.﻿

comments.author: Queen Katara

comments.text:
Disgusting work of lexicography! Good vocabulary by John. I was completely 
confused by the title of this video, I interpreted this as if he was saying 
he was arrested and charged with either possession or manufacturing. Also, 
even though a book may contain content like this, I recognize that I will 
hear this stuff, as in sexual acts, religion and substance abuse in real 
life, and that I will have to pay attention to those problems and knowing 
about it is one of the best defences. Knowing about the realities of real 
world issues makes one better able to fight those problems. Some of them 
might not even be problems, because for example, it is perfectly expected 
for married people to have children so sexual acts there is not unusual. 
Many people around the world, many respectable people drink a glass of wine 
after dinner or when at a birthday party they may have a bottle or can of 
beer. That is perfectly expected of people who are old enough, like in my 
province the age required is 18 but I would ask that they think long and 
hard about having any at that age, after 25-27 it is not unusual to have 
such drinking. Though smoking can't actually be defended and pornography is 
wrong, some issues are not actually issues. ﻿

comments.author: Leigh-ann

comments.text:
I have to admit, I've haven't read any of John's books.  I want to, just 
haven't got the money/time to buy/read them, and our local library isn't 
great.  That being said, I like the solution the school came up with, for 
any book that might be controversial.  That way individual parents can 
decide. Although I also think the  PARENTS should be required to read the 
book in question too so they don't jump to stupid conclusions based on what 
they've heard about the book through the grapevine.  Read and think for 
yourselves, people! Or at the very least trust that your kids are smart 
enough to know the difference between real life and a novel. What really 
burns me up though, is when certain people (some of which don't even have 
kids at that grade level or no kids at all.) decide that their opinions 
about a book they may or may not have even read (usually not) outweigh the 
opinions of the parents who are okay with their kid reading it.  Quit 
trying to parent other people's children! If you don't want your kids to 
read it, that's between you and your kid.  Talk to the teacher and see if 
they can do something else. But for the love of reading, don't try to take 
away an opportunity to read a good book away from other kids! I know this 
video is older, and I'm glad it got resolved, but the same issue is still 
going on with other books and it still turns me into a Giant Squid of 
Anger! Although, I will say there is one small upside: the more you forbid 
your kids to read something, the more they will want to read it.  Just 
saying.   I had a friend in middle school, her parents wouldn't let her 
read Harry Potter so I let her borrow my HP books all throughout middle and 
high school and she read them in secret.  Mostly just to spite her parents 
and see what all the hype was about at first, but it didn't take her long 
to fall in love with the series. Yeah...I aided a friend in disobeying her 
parents, and I'm proud of it.  She didn't turn into a Satan-worshipping 
cult leader from reading them either so no harm done :)﻿

think as 16/17 year olds we should have that choice. I was lucky be able to

comments.author: Nicole Guyor

comments.text:
In Portugal we read a book called "Os Maias" (translation : The Maias) in 
the 11th grade. In this book, a rich guy of the 19th century falls in love 
(and has sex) with with a young lady that later in the book discouvers to 
be his long lost sister. Everyone in the 11th in the whole country has to 
read it, and it's a loyal portrait of the portuguese society back in the 
day, comic and beatifully written, even tough some parts of it are 
controversial. My point is that Looking for Alaska isn't at any moment of 
the story pornographic. Its an amazing book and the bits that are 
controversial are there for a reason, to teach us teens that emocional 
connections are way more important that phisical ones... If a teen can read 
the Maias with a critical look, than a teen can certainly read Looking for 
Alaska and understand why the sex scene is there.﻿

comments.author: Icey Xaiver

comments.text:
I agree that it's not anyone's place to tell other people's kids what they 
should or should not be allowed to read. My problem is how little you seem 
to understand the argument that these people are putting forth.

Their position is that there are certain topics that are inherently 
titillating, no matter what you try to do to make them not so. If there was 
a movie version of this particular book, and the details of the scene in 
question were actually shown, it would be rated R or above. It wouldn't 
matter that the scene was not supposed to be titillating.

These are the people who believe nudity is porn, full stop. That is why 
they are referring to your book as porn--they see it as the equivalent of 
showing the subject in question on screen--and that subject was the 
mechanical acts of a form of sexual intercourse. They believe such 
descriptions are inherently titillating.

Again, I repeat--I agree wholeheartedly that these people were wrong to try 
and ban your book. The most they had the right to do was prevent their own 
children from being required to read it. But I don't think their point is 
what you portrayed it to be--that teens are too stupid to know the 
difference. They just object to titillation in general. And they think what 
you discuss in your book is inherently titillating--and thus, porn.﻿
comments.author: ZipplyZane
